<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CYBERSECURITY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/a-software-flaw-exposes-major-companies-servers?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Companies Feel Extra Insecure Ahead of the Holidays
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/a-software-flaw-exposes-major-companies-servers?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="A computer getting hacked" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e36a88a7dd74f11ece3c8b95a2a56f1cc9a3fdb2-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A piece of faulty software called Log4J has exposed major companies to over 1.2 million cyberattacks since last Friday, according to researchers. It’s already one of the <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/the-log4j-software-bug-could-put-your-favorite-sites-at-risk-what-you-need-to-know/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most wide-reaching</a> security breaches ever, and it could take years to fully fix. Awake yet?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The little-known but widely used Log4J software helps major companies, including Amazon, Apple, Tesla, IBM, and Twitter, log and track user activity across a range of applications. Now, cyberattackers are using it as a crowbar to break into computers. Once in, hackers can:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Extract sensitive data.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Mine crypto.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Join the computer to a “botnet”—a system of interconnected computers used to mass-send spam and perform other nefarious actions.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So far, the only company known to have been breached via Log4J is Microsoft, which had its servers for the video game <em>Minecraft</em> <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/12/13/22832552/iphone-tesla-sms-log4shell-log4j-exploit-researchers-test?scrolla=5eb6d68b7fedc32c19ef33b4" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hijacked</a>. Other companies are currently in investigation mode, so the full fallout is unknown.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Who’s getting fired over this goof?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">No one. Log4J was maintained by a team of volunteers who in their free time code for the nonprofit Apache Software Foundation. It’s one of dozens of open-source, volunteer-run organizations that create the free software that <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-13/how-apache-raced-to-fix-a-potentially-disastrous-software-flaw?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">underpins</a> most major companies’ operations.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So maybe blame it on the volunteers’ day jobs that, despite the flaw reportedly existing since 2013, the team wasn’t aware of it until an Alibaba employee sent a warning on Nov. 24. Within weeks, the code was out of the bag: Details of the flaw surfaced in conversations on Chinese social network WeChat and shortly after became global news.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What now? </strong>The volunteer team has already created a patch to fix the issue, but corporate software engineers have to adapt and deploy the update. Plus, hackers who walked into servers through the Log4J door likely broke some windows while in there, allowing them to circumvent the first patch.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The US government had already <a href="https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/fbi-and-cisa-issue-holiday-ransomware-cyberattack-warning/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">warned</a> companies last month to stay extra vigilant against online attacks ahead of the holidays, a popular period for hackers to strike.—<em>JW</em></p>
</div>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COVID
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/omicron-speed-round?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Covid Speed Round
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/omicron-speed-round?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt='A sign saying "mask up for Xmas" in Britain' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/41b959154a6fe086d814c92a8412f390f7dd7116-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Christopher Furlong/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Omicron in the US: </strong>Omicron <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-14/omicron-accounts-for-3-of-u-s-covid-cases-as-delta-reigns?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">accounts for 3%</a> of sequenced Covid-19 cases in the US, and it’s expected to keep spreading beyond the 33 states it’s already been found in, the CDC said. But Delta remains the dominant variant, making up 96% of sequenced cases in the country.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">School’s out: </strong>Cornell is <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/14/us/cornell-university-covid-cases/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">closing</a> its campus in Ithaca, NY, and moving all of its final exams online after observing the “rapid spread” of Covid-19 among its student body.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">iMask: </strong>Apple is <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/14/apple-will-require-masks-at-all-us-stores-because-of-rising-covid-cases.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">mandating</a> that shoppers wear masks at its stores nationwide.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The UK relaxes its travel ban: </strong>It’s taken 11 countries in southern Africa off its “travel red list,” saying there’s <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/business-59653236?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">no point</a> in banning travel when Omicron is already spreading widely across the world.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Sports disrupted: </strong>Professional leagues including the NBA, NHL, and English Premier League have <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/nfl-nba-covid-omicron-manchester-united-11639500554?mod=hp_major_pos3#cxrecs_s" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">postponed games</a> in recent days due to Covid outbreaks. 37 NFL players tested positive for Covid on Monday (the highest single-day total since the pandemic began) and the league is now requiring coaches and some other staff to get a booster shot by Dec. 27.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LABOR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/teacher-cash-grab-draws-major-criticism?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
America's Saddest Home Videos
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/teacher-cash-grab-draws-major-criticism?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="South Dakota teachers scramble for one dollar bills at a hockey game." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1cd45c7f034dd3430d504a235bf691713eeaec6a-2880x1602.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Twitter/@annietodd96</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So let’s get this straight: a video featuring local teachers scrambling <a href="https://twitter.com/annietodd96/status/1469835556691587076?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">on their hands and knees</a> for $5,000 in one-dollar bills to use on classroom supplies was posted online and people <em>didn’t </em>love it?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The “dash for cash” stunt—which has received nearly 20 million views on Twitter—took place at a South Dakota junior ice hockey game last Saturday. Ten teachers (out of 31 who applied) competed in the dystopian event, stuffing their shirts with dollar bills. Teacher takeaways ranged from $376 to $616.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Critics called the event “humiliating”—a gamification of economic inequality à la <em>Squid Game</em>. The dash for cash was criticized for making light of a bleak American reality, similar to the game show <em>Paid Off</em>, in which contestants with enormous amounts of student debt compete to have it wiped out. The reality in this case: South Dakota ranks 50th in the nation for teacher pay.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The mea culpa:</strong> In a joint statement, the home team and the local mortgage lender that funded the event apologized and acknowledged that it seemed degrading to the teaching profession. They’ve since pledged an additional $500 each to all teachers involved, including the applicants who didn’t compete.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/what-your-inflation-take-says-about-you?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
What Your Inflation Take Says About You
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Expectations around inflation tend to fluctuate depending on factors like age, income, and Hogwarts house (OK, not that one)—and the differences can be pretty significant.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The November results of the New York Fed’s <a href="https://www.newyorkfed.org/microeconomics/sce?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew#/inflexp-6" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Survey of Consumer Expectations</a>—which measures what different groups think the median inflation rate will be in three years—revealed that Americans...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Under 40:</strong></span><span> expect inflation to hit 3.5%</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Over 60:</strong></span><span> expect inflation to hit 4.7%</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Making less than $50k: </strong></span><span>expect inflation to hit 4.4%</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Making more than $100k:</strong></span><span> expect inflation to hit 3.4%</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why the big difference? </strong>Because we all live in different circumstances. More so than the youths, older Americans tend to rely on fixed incomes and personal savings, which suffer disproportionately from inflation. Similarly, an increase in the price of everyday goods hurts lower-income people more than those with higher salaries.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Inflation expectations are watched closely by economists because, for instance, if workers anticipate prices will rise in the future, then they may rally for higher wages, which in turn could generate more inflation. The Fed will try to manage those expectations with its big policy update later today.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Word Search: </strong>Connect ugly Christmas sweater designs to famous movies and TV shows in today’s puzzle. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/word-search-holiday-sweaters?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Play it here</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">2020 or 2021?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The final two years have been...how should we say this...a bit of a blur. We’ll give you a notable event and you have to figure out whether it happened in 2020 or 2021.</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The first Covid vaccine dose was administered</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The storming of the Capitol building</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Prince Harry and Meghan Markle said they would “step back” from the British royal family</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Brood X cicada emergence</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Strange monoliths were discovered in Utah, California, and Romania</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Bill and Melinda Gates announced their divorce</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Italy beat England at the Euro soccer tournament</span></li>
</ol>
</div>

href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/14/a-software-flaw-exposes-major-companies-servers?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A computer getting hacked\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e36a88a7dd74f11ece3c8b95a2a56f1cc9a3fdb2-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA piece of faulty software called Log4J has exposed major companies to over 1.2 million cyberattacks since last Friday, according to researchers. It’s already one of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/the-log4j-software-bug-could-put-your-favorite-sites-at-risk-what-you-need-to-know/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emost wide-reaching\u003c/a\u003e security breaches ever, and it could take years to fully fix. Awake yet?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe little-known but widely used Log4J software helps major companies, including Amazon, Apple, Tesla, IBM, and Twitter, log and track user activity across a range of applications. Now, cyberattackers are using it as a crowbar to break into computers. Once in, hackers can:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eExtract sensitive data.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMine crypto.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eJoin the computer to a “botnet”—a system of interconnected computers used to mass-send spam and perform other nefarious actions.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo far, the only company known to have been breached via Log4J is Microsoft, which had its servers for the video game \u003cem\u003eMinecraft\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/12/13/22832552/iphone-tesla-sms-log4shell-log4j-exploit-researchers-test?scrolla=5eb6d68b7fedc32c19ef33b4\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehijacked\u003c/a\u003e. Other companies are currently in investigation mode, so the full fallout is unknown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWho’s getting fired over this goof?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNo one. Log4J was maintained by a team of volunteers who in their free time code for the nonprofit Apache Software Foundation. It’s one of dozens of open-source, volunteer-run organizations that create the free software that \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-13/how-apache-raced-to-fix-a-potentially-disastrous-software-flaw?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunderpins\u003c/a\u003e most major companies’ operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo maybe blame it on the volunteers’ day jobs that, despite the flaw reportedly existing since 2013, the team wasn’t aware of it until an Alibaba employee sent a warning on Nov. 24. Within weeks, the code was out of the bag: Details of the flaw surfaced in conversations on Chinese social network WeChat and shortly after became global news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat now? \u003c/strong\u003eThe volunteer team has already created a patch to fix the issue, but corporate software engineers have to adapt and deploy the update. Plus, hackers who walked into servers through the Log4J door likely broke some windows while in there, allowing them to circumvent the first patch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe US government had already \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/fbi-and-cisa-issue-holiday-ransomware-cyberattack-warning/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewarned\u003c/a\u003e companies last month to stay extra vigilant against online attacks ahead of the holidays, a popular period for hackers to strike.—\u003cem\u003eJW\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1cd45c7f034dd3430d504a235bf691713eeaec6a-2880x1602.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eTwitter/@annietodd96\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo let’s get this straight: a video featuring local teachers scrambling \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/annietodd96/status/1469835556691587076?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eon their hands and knees\u003c/a\u003e for $5,000 in one-dollar bills to use on classroom supplies was posted online and people \u003cem\u003edidn’t \u003c/em\u003elove it?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe “dash for cash” stunt—which has received nearly 20 million views on Twitter—took place at a South Dakota junior ice hockey game last Saturday. Ten teachers (out of 31 who applied) competed in the dystopian event, stuffing their shirts with dollar bills. Teacher takeaways ranged from $376 to $616.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCritics called the event “humiliating”—a gamification of economic inequality à la \u003cem\u003eSquid Game\u003c/em\u003e. The dash for cash was criticized for making light of a bleak American reality, similar to the game show \u003cem\u003ePaid Off\u003c/em\u003e, in which contestants with enormous amounts of student debt compete to have it wiped out. The reality in this case: South Dakota ranks 50th in the nation for teacher pay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe mea culpa:\u003c/strong\u003e In a joint statement, the home team and the local mortgage lender that funded the event apologized and acknowledged that it seemed degrading to the teaching profession. They’ve since pledged an additional $500 each to all teachers involved, including the applicants who didn’t compete.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL inflation tend to fluctuate depending on factors like age, income, and Hogwarts house (OK, not that one)—and the differences can be pretty significant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe November results of the New York Fed’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.newyorkfed.org/microeconomics/sce?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew#/inflexp-6\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSurvey of Consumer Expectations\u003c/a\u003e—which measures what different groups think the median inflation rate will be in three years—revealed that Americans...\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eUnder 40:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e expect inflation to hit 3.5%\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOver 60:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e expect inflation to hit 4.7%\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMaking less than $50k: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eexpect inflation to hit 4.4%\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMaking more than $100k:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e expect inflation to hit 3.4%\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy the big difference? \u003c/strong\u003eBecause we all live in different circumstances. More so than the youths, older Americans tend to rely on fixed incomes and personal savings, which suffer disproportionately from inflation. Similarly, an increase in the price of everyday goods hurts lower-income people more than those with higher salaries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Inflation expectations are watched closely by economists because, for instance, if workers anticipate prices will rise in the future, then they may rally for higher wages, which in turn could generate more inflation.
